statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

article.description: Wally Szczerbiak scored 30 points as the Timberwolves ended a slump and the first half of the season with a 113-103 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.
article.headline: Szczerbiak heads to first All-Star Game on high note

images.name: Wells_Bonzi 020602 inline
images.caption: Portland's Bonzi Wells races Joe Smith to a loose ball under the hoop.

article.linkText: Wolves' Szczerbiak rediscovers his touch, torches Blazers for 30
article.story:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- Wally Szczerbiak returned to form, and the Minnesota Timberwolves followed. Szczerbiak ended his scoring struggles with 30 points, six rebounds and five assists and led the Timberwolves to a 113-103 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers on Wednesday night. "That was a nice stress-reliever game," Szczerbiak said with a smile. The Timberwolves won for just the third time in nine games and cooled off the Blazers, who allowed a season-high point total and lost for only the fifth time in 17 games. Each Portland starter scored in double figures, and Bonzi Wells led the way with a career-high 35 points. "Bonzi got hot when we needed someone to, but we needed to do so much to get back in the game," Blazers coach Maurice Cheeks said. "They made a statement on the defensive end early." Szczerbiak had a season-low three points Jan. 29 -- the same night he was named to the All-Star team -- and 10 points on 4-for-16 shooting on Monday. Szczerbiak and teammate Kevin Garnett had been frustrated recently with his lack of touches on offense, but Szczerbiak made up for it by going 11-for-16 from the floor and 5-for-5 from the foul line. "When we have faith in each other and help each other and move the ball, we're playing Timberwolves basketball," Szczerbiak said. "It's a lot of fun to watch and a lot of fun to play." Minnesota shot 57 percent from the field, but better defense was ultimately the slump-snapper. The Timberwolves have surrendered 100 points or more in 12 of 16 games, but they were tough when it mattered most against the Blazers. "Wally not scoring had nothing to do with the offense," Minnesota coach Flip Saunders said. "It had to do with defense. If we're defending well, Wally's a good finisher, so guys get it out to him in the open floor." Joe Smith had 21 points, and reserve Gary Trent added 14 for Minnesota, which was coming off a 30-point loss to San Antonio Monday. Portland made a season-high 11 3-pointers but had only one reserve score any points: Ruben Patterson, who had two. Damon Stoudamire had 19 points and 10 assists, Scottie Pippen had 16 points and 10 assists and Dale Davis had 13 points and 15 rebounds for Portland. Portland closed within 73-66 in the third period on Stoudamire's fourth 3-pointer of the quarter, cut the lead to seven several times down the stretch but couldn't get closer. The game was basically decided in the first period, when Minnesota shot 68 percent from the field and Portland missed 12 of 18 shots. "They hit so many shots," Wells said. "They were hitting from all angles. It was tough to recover. By the time we figured out what they were doing and learned how to stop it, we were down 15." The Timberwolves jumped to a 16-5 lead and extended it to 23 points when Szczerbiak's 3-pointer put them ahead 49-26 with 6:06 left before halftime. Minnesota committed only three turnovers and had a franchise record-tying 24 assists in the first half. Chauncey Billups, starting for the injured Terrell Brandon, had 13 of his 18 points for Minnesota in the first half. Garnett, who had a string of 338 games scoring in double digits broken Monday, added 14 points for the Wolves. "We're not totally happy because of where we were," Saunders said, "but we fought through this stretch and now we get some time off. If we play the way we're supposed to, moving the basketball, low turnovers and defending, the wins and losses will take care of themselves."

Game notes
Brandon was held out with a sore left knee. "It's swelled up and it's stiff, and it's proven to us that as a point guard you can't be at 80 or 85 percent," Timberwolves coach Flip Saunders said before the game. "We think the rest will help him." ... Minnesota, which still has the NBA's fifth-best record despite its recent slump, made its first appearance of the season on national TV. That leaves three other teams (Cleveland, Memphis and Seattle) who haven't played on TNT, TBS or NBC this season. ... ... Portland's Chris Dudley drew a technical foul in the second quarter for bumping into ex-teammate Trent, who was grinning, at the foul line. Official Bernie Fryer thought Dudley was angry, but Dudley didn't, unsuccessfully pleading to Fryer, "Hey, we're friends!"
